SIC-Based Output Product Code Arrangement 359 Revisions in Calendar Year 1977 Data 363 EXPLANATION OF STATISTICS Imports of Commodities Based on the Standard Industrial Classification Purpose and Scope In this publication the import data, which are initially compiled under the approximately 10,000 classes of the Tariff Schedules of the United States Annotated (TSUSA), are arranged and summarized into about 2,500 classes of a commodity classification based on the origin of production, that is, within industries1 primarily responsible for their output. This rearrangement of the import data into a structure related to the origin of production should facilitate the comparison by commodities of the U.S. import statistics with other data related to the domestic economy. Since imports were originally compiled in terms of an unrelated commodity classification (the TSUSA), a com- plete and precise presentation of imports in terms of the output commodity classification based on the SIC is not possible. However, this arrangement does identify for the user the import data which are most comparable to output data for individual commodities, and presents the infor- mation in convenient form for such further summarization as he finds appropriate for his purpose. It should be emphasized that the import data thus derived relate to imported commodities organized within the domestic industry classifications of the SIC and that statistics on commodity output (classified in terms of the TSUSA) and those on industrial activity of individual domestic industries seldom bear a one-to-one relationship even though measured within the same general framework. some TSUSA commodity numbers to SIC-based output product classifications on the basis of judgment. TSUSA commodity numbers often include items which should be classified in two or more SIC output product codes. In cases where a judgment could be made that the TSUSA classification could be assigned to the SIC output product code in which its principal content appeared to belong without significantly overcounting the classification to which it was assigned or significantly undercounting others in which it partly belonged, such an assignment was made. Where it appeared that assigning the entire content to a single SIC output product code would seriously distort the import data under one or more such codes, the output product codes (or those principally affected, if more than two were involved) were combined for purposes of this presentation and the TSUSA number was assigned to the combination. This method of dealing with cases where a direct match could not be made has minimized distortion of the import data under the individual SIC output product codes. Combinations of output product codes are identified in separate tables in this report entitled "Principal Differences Between the SIC-Based Output and Import Product Codes." In the import product numbering system, a sixth digit was used to identify combinations of 5-digit codes: (0) in- dicating no combination and the letters A-E, G, H and J, representing combinations crossing various levels of the SIC structure. When all of the 5-digit output commodity classes of a 4-digit industry group were combined, the fifth and sixth digits are "XX." The Product Classifications Used in This Report For the purpose of relating import statistics to produc- tion data compiled under the SIC system, the 5-digit product classes of the Numerical List of Manufactured Products, 1977 Census of Manufactures (MC77-R-1) were used as the starting point for manufactured products. The 4-digit industries of the SIC subdivided into 5-digit homo- geneous classes of commodities were used as the starting point for nonmanufactured products. However, in relating the TSUSA classifications to such an SIC-based output product classification there were instances where overlaps in these two classification systems made it necessary to assign 'Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972 and its 1977 Supplement, issued by the Office of Management and Budget. The seventh and eighth digits are further subdivisions of the 6-digit code. Such subdivisions have been made to yield import classifications comparable to output commodity classifications within the framework of the SIC. The SIC-based 8-digit import classes have been selected on the basis of the availability of comparable output data from published government sources. The descriptions used in this report reflect as closely as possible the actual TSUSA content of the 8-digit item. However, they are necessarily abbreviated and therefore do not contain all of the qualifying information necessary to define clearly the commodity for which statistics are shown. For complete definitions of the individual SIC-based import product classifications, reference should be made to the definitions of the TSUSA classifications included. V VI Relationship Between the Import and Export SIC-Based Product Codes Annual export data comparable to the import statistics in this report are published in FT 610, U.S. Exports of Domestic Merchandise, SIC-Based Products and Area. The export data, originally compiled in accordance with about 4,000 classifications listed in Schedule B, Statistical Classifi- cation of Domestic and Foreign Commodities Exported from the United States, are rearranged and summarized into approximately 3,000 SIC-based export product codes. The export classes were derived from the Standard Industrial Classification in the same manner as the import classes presented in this publication. However, since the import classes were derived from the TSUSA and the export classes from Schedule B, it was not always possible to establish identical classifications for both imports and exports. Nor was it possible to assign commodity code numbers so that identical numbers in the two reports would in all cases reflect identical coverage. When comparisons are made between the import data in this report and the export data in FT 6 1 0, further information regarding the coverage of the SIC-based product codes should be obtained by referring to the definitions of the individual import TSUSA classifications and export Schedule B classifications in- cluded under the SIC-based product codes. Related Information A tabulation identified as IA-276, U.S. Imports for Consumption and General Imports, SIC-Based 8-digit Product Code by Country of Origin, is prepared annually for the benefit of those users of the data who may be interested in country of origin rather than area detail for the SIC-based commodity classifications used in this report. Copies of this tabulation are available for reference use at Department of Commerce Field Offices located in principal cities. The Bureau has, since 1958, been publishing an annual re- port in the ES-2 series entitled U.S. Commodity Exports and Imports as Related to Output. In a single publication, this report relates both exports and imports to output on a con- sistent basis. It also annotates the comparisons, indicating noncomparabilities and variations in actual and intended content. The import data shown therein are derived from the SIC-based import commodity data of this Report FT 210, using the same commodity detail or aggregating as appropriate. Additional information regarding the sources mentioned above may be obtained from the Bureau of the Census. Source of Import Statistics The official U.S. import statistics are compiled by the Bureau of the Census from copies of the import entry and warehouse withdrawal forms which importers are required by law to file with Customs officials. The information as to country of origin, net quantity, value, and commodity classification is verified by Cutoms officials on entries filed for transactions valued over $250, which are ordinarily subject to examination for Customs appraisement purposes. The statistical copy of the entry is corrected if it does not accurately reflect the information called for by the sta- tistical requirements. Information on warehouse with- drawals, which account for approximatley 4 percent of the total value of imports for consumption, while not subject to the verification procedure directly, should be improved indirectly (due to education of importers/brokers) by the verification of the warehouse entries to which they corre- spond. Coverage of the Import Statistics The import statistics reflect both government and non- government imports of merchandise into the U.S. Customs area (includes the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico) without regard to whether the importation involves a commercial transaction. The statistics exclude the following: Shipments between the United States and Puerto Rico, between the United States and its possessions (including the Virgin Islands), and between these outlying areas; imports into U.S. possessions; American goods returned to the United States by U.S. Armed Forces; intransit shipments through the United States; shipments not considered to be imports for statistical purposes or shipments of relatively small significance in terms of total value or statistical importance, such as personal and household effects, temporary imports, and low-valued nondutiable imports by mail; and issued monetary coins of all component metals. (Imports of nonmonetary gold in such forms as ore, scrap, base bullion, refined bullion, etc., which were previously excluded, are included in the regular import statistics effective January 1978.) General Imports/ Imports for Consumption Imported merchandise is reported as "General Imports" and "Imports for Consumption." General imports are a combination of entries for immediate consumption and entries into Customs bonded warehouses. With certain exceptions as indicated above, these data reflect total arrivals of merchandise, whether such merchandise enters consumption channels immediately or is entered into warehouses under Customs' custody to be subsequently withdrawn for consumption or withdrawn for exportation. The general import statistics, therefore, reflect merchandise entered for immediate consumption ("duty free" mer- chandise, merchandise on which duty is paid on arrival, and merchandise entered into Customs bonded manufacturing warehouses for processing and subsequent export of the main product) plus merchandise entered into Customs bonded storage warehouses and Customs bonded smelting and refining warehouses. Imports for consumption are a combination of entries for immediate consumption and withdrawals from warehouses for consumption. With certain exceptions as indicated above, these data reflect the total of commodities entered into U.S. consumption channels. Imports for consumption statistics include merchandise entered for immediate con- sumption (as parenthetically explained above) plus mer- chandise withdrawn from Customs bonded storage ware- houses for consumption, merchandise withdrawn from Customs bonded smelting and refining warehouses, and merchandise transferred from Customs bonded storage warehouses to Customs bonded manufacturing warehouses for manufacturing and export. Monthly and Annual Carryover It is the objective of the compiling procedures to include shipments, insofar as practicable, in the statistics for the actual month of importation (or the month of withdrawal in the case of warehouse withdrawals for consumption). Effective with the January 1978 statistics, the date of importation as reported on the import entries is being used to determine the statistical month. (Prior to 1978, the date of Customs official acceptance of the import entry docu- ments was used to determine the statistical month in which the shipments were included.) However, since under the Customs "immediate-delivery" procedures importers may file the import entry up to 10 workdays after the date of release of the merchandise, some documents for merchandise imported during the last few days of a given month may not be received in time for inclusion in the statistics for that month. As a result, there is a carryover, estimated at about 15 percent, from the actual month of importation to a subsequent month. In addition, processing problems (e.g., late filing of documents, rejection of a shipment by the computer because the data fail to meet certain edit criteria established to protect the accuracy of the statistics, etc.) contribute to an additional carryover of about 5 percent (in terms of value) of shipments from the reported month of importation (or withdrawal from warehouse) to a subse- quent month, usually the succeeding month. Normally the amount of carryover from month to month and year to year remains substantially constant so that comparisons of overall totals from period to period are not unduly affected. However, monthly or yearly compari- sons of individual figures may be affected since statistics at a more detailed level may include some shipments made during a previous period without a corresponding carryover to the following period. Import Valuation The value shown in this report is the f.a.s. (free alongside ship) value, which represents the transaction value of im- ports at the foreign port of exportation. It is based on the purchase price, i.e., the actual transaction value and generally includes all charges incurred in placing the mer- chandise alongside the carrier at the port of exportation in the country of exportation. Area of Origin This report presents information on imports of com- modities into the United States from major world areas. The areas represent groupings of individual countries, with the exceptions of Canada, the United Kingdom, the Federal Republic of Germany, and Japan which are treated as separate areas. A listing of the areas and the individual countries included in each area is contained in this report. VII The area of origin, as shown in this report, reflects the summarization of the information reported by importers or their brokers regarding the country of origin of individual import shipments. The country of origin is defined as the country where the merchandise was grown, mined, or manufactured. In instances where it is known that the country of origin cannot be determined, the transactions are credited to the country of shipment. A complete list of the countries for which import data are compiled is contained in Schedule C-I, Classification of Country and Territory Designations for U.S. Import Statis- tics, which replaced the former Schedule C, effective Jan- uary 1976. Copies of Schedule C-I are available free upon request to the Bureau of the Census. The schedule is also published as Annex B in Tariff Schedules of the United States Annotated. Estimated Data for Low-Valued Imports The import statistics include estimated data for ship- ments valued under $251 reported on both formal and informal entries. (Informal entries generally contain items valued under $251.) The estimates, which are based on a 1-percent sample following standard practice, are included along with other items under commodity number 990000 00, "Miscellaneous Commodities, N.E.S." The statistics for commodity codes from which the low-valued shipments are excluded are undercounted to the extent that such low-valued shipments of the particular commodity are made. The total value so excluded generally amounts to less than 1 percent of the yearly import total. The estimated value totals for commodity number 990000 00 are subject to variability because a sample was taken. For any given trade area shown under commodity number 990000 00, the approximate sampling variability may be found by reference to the table shown on the preceding page. As an example the figure in the sampling variability column for Japan is $1,155,000. This means the chances are better than 2 out of 3 that a complete tabulation would have resulted in a figure within about $1,155,000 of the total shown for commodity number 990000 00 for Japan. Sources of Error in the Statistics Import figures are subject to the possibility of errors which may arise from various sources. Among these are errors in the reporting and/or processing of information as to commodity classification, net quantity, value and other sta- tistical factors, month or year of inclusion in the statistics (see the explanation regarding Monthly and Annual Carry- over, above), and errors which may result from the sampling of shipments valued under $251. (See the explanation regarding Estimated Data for Low-Valued Imports.) As in- dicated above under Source of Information, the information as to net quantity, value, commodity classification, and country of origin is verified by Customs officials on entries filed for transactions valued over $250 which are ordinarily subject to examination for Customs appraisement purposes, thus considerably reducing the possibility of error. In addition, the procedures used to compile the statistics in- clude clerical and computer processing checks designed to protect the accuracy of the statistics to the fullest prac- ticable extent. Sources of Further Information About Foreign Trade Statistics Summary import and export statistics are presented in the monthly issues of Report FT 900, Summary of Export and Import Merchandise Trade, and in Report FT 990, Highlights of U.S. Export and Import Trade. More detailed monthly and cumulative import commodity data are pre- sented in Report FT 135, U.S. General Imports, Schedule A Commodity by Country. Annual data are presented in Report FT 150, U.S. General Imports, Schedule A Com- modity Groupings, World Area, Country, and Method of Transportation; Report FT 155, U.S. General Imports, World Area, Country, Schedule A Commodity Groupings, and Method of Transportation; and Report FT 246, U.S. Imports for Consumption and General Imports, TSUSA Commodity by Country. Further information regarding the foreign trade statistics program is contained in the Guide to Foreign Trade Statistics. The Guide contains an explanation of the coverage of the statistics and sample illustrations of the content and arrangement of the data presented in individual reports and tabulations. Supplementary information and explanations of interest to users of foreign trade statistics (such as notices of changes in types of shipments covered by current statistics, unusual shipments, problems of valuation and classification, changes in statistical procedures, etc.) are included as special announcements in current issues of the statistical publications. Copies of foreign trade reports and tabulations are available for public reference use at Department of Commerce field offices and other reference locations. Reports providing additional detail compiled but not published can be obtained on a cost basis. A discussion of the history of foreign trade statistics, containing references to additional sources of historical trade data, appears in Historical Statistics of the United States, published by the Bureau of the Census. Copies are available at most libraries. For further information regarding the foreign trade statistics, request should be made to the Foreign Trade Division, Bureau of the Census, Washington, D.C. 20233.
